LARA - Der Deutsche Games Award }} '''Alexey Leonidovich Pajitnov'''{{efn|{{lang-rus|links=no|Алексей Леонидович Пажитнов|p=ɐlʲɪˈksʲej lʲɪɐˈnʲidəvʲɪtɕ ˈpaʐɨtnəf}}}} (born 14 March 1956) is a Russian [[video game designer]] and [[Computer engineering|computer engineer]] who developed ''[[Tetris]]'' while working for the [[Dorodnitsyn Computing Centre]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Soviet Academy of Sciences]], a Soviet government-founded [[Research and development|R&D]] center. He only started to get royalties from his creation in 1996 when he and [[Henk Rogers]] formed [[The Tetris Company]].{{cite web|url=http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/special/tetrishist.html |title=Tetris: a history |publisher=Atarihq.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-06}} ==Biography== Pajitnov was born on 14 March 1956 in [[Moscow]], in the [[Soviet Union]]. He studied [[applied mathematics]] at the [[Moscow Aviation Institute]].{{cite web |url=https://tetris.com/bios#alexey |title=Alexey Pajitnov, Creator of Tetris |author= |website=tetris.com |publisher=tetris holding |access-date=2018-08-05 |quote="He received his Masters degree in Applied Mathematics from the Moscow Institute of Aviation"}}{{cite web |title=History of Computers and Computing, Birth of the modern computer, Software history, Tetris of Alexey Pajitnov |url=https://history-computer.com/ModernComputer/Software/Tetris.html |website=history-computer.com |accessdate=10 March 2019}} He then went on to work on speech recognition at the [[Dorodnitsyn Computing Centre]] where he would develop the first version of [[Tetris]] on an [[Electronika 60]] computer in 1984. As a child, he was a fan of puzzles and played with [[pentomino]] toys.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/interview-with-the-tetris-company-creators-alexei-pajitnov-and-henk-rogers/|title=Meet the men who built the only perfect video game: Tetris|website=Digital Trends|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}} In creating ''Tetris'', he drew inspiration from these toys. Pajitnov created ''Tetris'' with the help of Dmitry Pavlovsky and [[Vadim Gerasimov]] in 1984. The game, first available in the Soviet Union, appeared in the West in 1986. Pajitnov also created a sequel to ''Tetris'', entitled ''[[Welltris]]'', which has the same principle but in a [[3D computer graphics|three-dimensional]] environment where the player sees the playing area from above.{{cite web|url=http://www.mds.mdh.se/~frv95pen/game/tetris/welltris/ |title=Screenshots from Welltris, retrieved 31-10-2007 |publisher=Mds.mdh.se |accessdate=2009-11-20 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060422232106/http://www.mds.mdh.se/~frv95pen/game/tetris/welltris/ |archivedate=2006-04-22 }} ''Tetris'' was licensed and managed by Soviet company [[ELORG]], which had a monopoly on the import and export of computer hardware and software in the Soviet Union, and advertised with the slogan ''"From Russia with Love"'' (on NES: ''"From Russia with Fun!"''). Because he was employed by the Soviet government, Pajitnov did not receive royalties. Pajitnov, together with [[Vladimir Pokhilko]], moved to the [[United States]] in 1991 and later, in 1996, founded [[The Tetris Company]] with Henk Rogers, which finally allowed him to collect royalties from his game. He helped design the puzzles in the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]] versions of ''[[Yoshi's Cookie]]'' and designed the game ''[[Pandora's Box (1999 video game)|Pandora's Box]]'', which incorporates more traditional [[jigsaw puzzle|jigsaw-style puzzles]]. He was employed by [[Microsoft]] from October 1996 until 2005. While there he worked on the ''[[Microsoft Entertainment Pack: The Puzzle Collection]]'', MSN Mind Aerobics and [[MSN Games]] groups. Pajitnov's new, enhanced version of ''[[Hexic]]'', ''Hexic HD'', was included with every new [[Xbox 360]] Premium package. On 18 August 2005, WildSnake Software announced that Pajitnov would be collaborating with them to release a new line of puzzle games.{{cite web|url=http://www.wildsnake.com/newsletter/2005-08-18/ |title=WildSnake newsletter 18 August 2005, retrieved 31-10-2007 |publisher=Wildsnake.com |date=2005-08-18 |accessdate=2009-11-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091112184900/http://www.wildsnake.com/newsletter/2005-08-18/| archivedate= 12 November 2009 | url-status= live}} ==Personal life== Pajitnov's son, Dmitri, died in a skiing accident on [[Mount Rainier]] in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://dmitripajitnov.com/ |title=Dmitri Pajitnov - In Memoriam, retrieved February 9, 2018 | url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/article168633372.html | title=Skier identified after body was missing for a month on Mount Rainier, retrieved Feb 9, 2018 | publisher=The News Tribune| date=2017-08-22| url-status=live}} ==Works== {|class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- ! The award was given for pioneering the casual games market.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=12732 |title=2007 Game Developers Choice Awards To Honor Miyamoto, Pajitnov |website=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=2007-02-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070307054731/http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=12732| archivedate= 7 March 2007 | url-status= live}} On 24 June 2009, he received the honorary award at the LARA - Der Deutsche Games Award in [[Cologne|Cologne, Germany]].{{cite web|url= http://www.heise.de/newsticker/Games-Award-ehrt-Tetris-Erfinder-Paschitnow--/meldung/141061|title=News report on Deutsche Games Award 2009 |publisher=[[Heinz Heise|Heise.de]]|accessdate=2009-06-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090626082322/http://www.heise.de/newsticker/Games-Award-ehrt-Tetris-Erfinder-Paschitnow--/meldung/141061| archivedate= 26 June 2009 | url-status= live}} In 2012, [[IGN]] included Pajitnov on their list of 5 Memorable Video Game Industry One-Hit Wonders, calling him "the ultimate video game one-hit wonder."{{cite web|first=Luke|last=Reilly|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/04/29/5-memorable-video-game-industry-one-hit-wonders|title=5 Memorable Video Game Industry One-Hit Wonders - Games Feature at IGN |website=IGN|accessdate=2012-05-06}} On 2015, Pajitnov won the Bizkaia Award at the [[Fun & Serious Game Festival]]{{cite web |title=F&S 2015 BIZKAIA AWARD |url=https://en.funandseriousgamefestival.com/alexey-pajitnov/}}{{cite web |title=El inventor del Tetris desvela su exito |url=https://www.elmundo.es/pais-vasco/2015/11/29/565add1a22601dc5228b458e.html |accessdate=8 July 2019}} ==See also== *''[[BreakThru!
